title: ben nevis climbers urged take home banana skins climate slows
story: The Real3Peaks Challenge team collected 8kg of banana skins on Ben NevisClimbers are being urged to stop leaving banana skins and orange peel on Britain’s most popular mountains as they essentially freeze and fail to biodegrade.Mountain conservation teams looking after Ben Nevis and Snowdon have called for visitors to treat “organic litter” as they would other litter, because they can take two years to decompose in the cold climate.The calls follow a “surge” in visitor numbers to the country's tallest mountain, Ben Nevis.  Last week, the Real3Peaks Challenge litter pickers collected 8kg of banana skins on the mountain.The waste, which is discarded by the hundreds of thousands of visitors to the mountains, is often left to the clean-up teams to collect as walkers assume the fruits will take just weeks to decompose.The Snowdonia National Park Authority complained that when every climber carries a snack the waste left behind is “significant” and takes years to disappear.They said that the eventual biodegrading process can also be problematic for the natural environment and changes the acidity of the soil.The conservation charity the John Muir trust added that it collected 1,000 banana skins from the Ben Nevis summit during a clean-up of litter in 2009 but it is a growing issue.The eventual biodegrading process can also be problematic for the natural environment and changes the acidity of the soil.“The cold weather is the issue, the break down process is far slower and takes up to two years. Some portions of the mountain are sub-zero all year round where the sun doesn’t reach, it's pretty much a subarctic climate,” a spokesperson for the John Muir trust said.“It varies from year to year but in some parts for most of the year it's like being frozen.”The teams at the John Muir trust who lead the clean up of Ben Nevis said that that an increase in visitors has caused more problems than ever when it comes to climbers leaving rubbish on the mountain.Ben Nevis: the facts bigThe mountain ordinarily sees 120,000 take on the summit a year, but last year over 160,000 people visited Ben Nevis.A spokesperson added: “Although there's been a lot more improvements with litter due to a much greater awareness, it’s got worse recently.“There’s been a surge in visitors to Ben Nevis and the popularity for the Highlands is growing due to social media bringing it to life. “Where these kinds of visitors might not go the whole way up some mountains, they all go up Ben Nevis it’s not just experienced walkers who are more aware when it comes to climbing and dropping litter.”Peter Rutherford, the Snowdonia National Park Authority’s Access Officer said: “If you have 550,000 walkers a year on Snowdon alone and everybody has an apple or a banana in their bag, then this is a significant amount of organic waste that will take a few years to decompose. “It’s unfortunate that people don’t equate litter with organic litter. They think it's acceptable but obviously it's not,  even in the countryside. title: apollo 11 moon landing rocket lunar saturn v neil armstrong buzz aldrin michael collins
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options'We are in the shadow of the Moon now, and the elusive stars have reappeared'Click to followThe Independent TechOn this day 50 years ago, the Apollo astronauts who were being hailed as heroes didn't have all that much to do. They were a central part of a mission watched around the world, one which would define the century that followed, and which required intensive intelligence and ingenuity beyond our imagining&nbsp– but at the moment they were engaged in housekeeping and sleeping.Now is the anniversary of perhaps the most unusual part of the Moon mission: that intermediate period after astronauts had completed the all-important liftoff, and as they waited, quietly drifting through space, on their way to the Moon.The launch happened on 16 July, 1969. The landing happened four days later, on 20 July.Between those days were a strange and eerie silence, filled with activities that would be humdrum were they not happening inside of the most ambitious activity ever launched by humankind.As the three astronauts – Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins –&nbspfloated serenely through space, they began to think about what would happen at Earth. They were travelling at immense speed which meant that they had left the Earth quicker than many of those who had come along to watch would be able to get out of the parking lots they'd viewed it from.Created with Sketch. To the left of the US flag in the background is the lunar surface television camera.Buzz Aldrin stands next to a lunar seismometer.Neil Armstrong works near the lunar landing module.Members of the Apollo 11 crew wait to be picked up by a helicopter from the USS Hornet on 24 July 1969.US president Richard Nixon welcomes the Apollo 11 astronauts, confined to a mobile quarantine facility, aboard the USS Hornet.As we proceed outbound, this number will get smaller and smaller until the tug of the Moon's gravity exceeds that of the Earth's and then we will start speeding up again, Collins later said.&nbspIt's hard to believe that we are on our way to the Moon, at 1200 miles altitude now, less than three hours after liftoff, and I'll bet the launch-day crowd down at the Cape is still bumper to bumper, straggling back to the motels and bars.Soon after that, they would get to the main work they had to do during the journey, which began early. Collins was assisted by his two colleagues to separate the command module from the third stage of the Saturn rocket, and then spin it around and connect with the lunar module known as Eagle that would be used to descend to the service.Apollo 11 launch video shows immense power of Saturn V rocketThis of course was a critical maneuver in the flight plan, Aldrin later said.&nbspIf the separation and docking did not work, we would return to Earth.There was also the possibility of an in-space collision and the subsequent decompression of our cabin, so we were still in our spacesuits as Mike separated us from the Saturn third stage. Critical as the maneuver is, I felt no apprehension about it, and if there was the slightest inkling of concern it disappeared quickly as the entire separation and docking proceeded perfectly to completion.The nose of Columbia was now connected to the top of the Eagle and heading for the Moon as we watched the Saturn third stage venting, a propulsive maneuver causing it to move slowly away from us.After that was completed, the really stressful work was over. The astronauts could get to sitting out the journey, waiting until they reached their distant target.By the next day, the astronauts were able to darken the windows with covers that served as curtains, and try and get some sleep as the command module slowly rotated them through space. They'd spend the following days doing chores and talking with Earth.During those intermediate days, there was considerably less activity on board the craft. Nasa's official timeline – which gives detailed information on absolutely everything the crew did – lists only a few activities over the course of the 17th and 18th, as the three astronauts floated through space.On 17 July, for instance, the crew simply conducted three TV transmissions and did one small burn of their engines to correct their course. The day after, there was another TV transmission and a quick journey into the lunar module and back so that it could be inspected ahead of the landing.But the day later, as they approached the Moon and, the atmosphere would change.Day four&nbsphas a decidedly different feel to it, Collins later said.&nbspInstead of nine hours' sleep, I get seven –&nbspand fitful ones at that.Despite our concentrated effort to conserve our energy on the way to the Moon, the pressure is overtaking us (or me at least), and I feel that all of us are aware that the honeymoon is over and we are about to lay our little pink bodies on the line.At this point, everything became much more real: for one, the astronauts could once again see the Moon properly for the first time in nearly a day. They were now in orbit around the Moon, and it was vividly clear.The Moon I have known all my life, that two-dimensional small yellow disk in the sky, has gone away somewhere, to be replaced by the most awesome sphere I have ever seen, said Collins later.To begin with it is huge, completely filling our window. Second, it is three-dimensional. The belly of it bulges out&nbsptoward&nbspus in such a pronounced fashion that I almost feel I can reach out and touch it. To add to the dramatic effect, we can see the stars again. We are in the shadow of the Moon now, and the elusive stars have reappeared.At this point, the work to get ready to touch the lunar surface begins. The astronauts each carry out the checks that would try and ensure that the descent was as safe as possible, and that the lander that would carry them down was as secure as it could possibly be.Collins would spent yet more time on his own, waiting, as Aldrin and Armstrong jumped around the lunar surface. As they did, he waited, floating above the Moon – occasionally disappearing behind it and being plunged into the all-consuming quiet of the far side of the Moon –&nbspand waiting for his two colleagues to make their return, before heading back to Earth.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsReal household incomes have fallen by 0.5 per cent over past two years amid pound’s slide and welfare cutsClick to followThe IndependentThe Brexit vote coupled with austerity has hurt household incomes more than anything other than recessions in the past 60 years and has done even more damage than the economic slump of the early 1990s, research has found.&nbspTypical household incomes have fallen by 0.5 per cent over the past two years compared with a rise of 0.3 per cent between 1991 and 1993, when the economy was going through and then recovering from recession, according to the annual Living Standards Audit by the Resolution Foundation.&nbspThe report dubs the latest period “Article 50 (so far)” in reference to the start of Britain’s withdrawal from the EU in March 2017.“Brexit has dominated the political landscape over the last three years, and even now it remains unclear just what form the UK’s exit from the EU will take,” it said.&nbsp“This uncertainty has already had a clear impact on growth and on living standards.”It added: “High inflation following the post-referendum sterling devaluation led to another fall&nbspin real wages. Housing costs were also deducted to account for income differences between outright homeowners, mortgage holders and renters.&nbspThe recent drop in incomes forms part of a wider stagnation in living standards since the financial crisis, caused primarily by a severe slowdown in productivity growth, the Resolution Foundation said.&nbsp“Restoring this – via greater investment in skills and capital across the UK, and resolving Brexit uncertainty – should be a top priority for the next prime minister,” it added.Rising output per hour accounted for two-thirds of&nbspthe UK's overall economic growth before the financial crash, but just&nbspover a fifth of growth since then, the report noted. Population growth has replaced productivity gains as the engine of economic expansion since 2007.&nbsp&nbspBritain predicted to fall into recession after no-deal BrexitAverage household incomes&nbsphave been propped up since then by&nbspmore people entering work and a halt to a century-long decline in working hours.The researchers also found that income inequality has “rocketed” over the past half-century and called on the next leader of the country to ensure a more equal distribution of income growth.However, that is the opposite of what the ongoing leadership campaign has focused on, they said&nbsp–&nbspin apparent criticism of Boris Johnson, the frontrunner, who has promised to raise the threshold at which the higher rate of income tax kicks in. title: brexit economy uk living standards household income recession
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsReal household incomes have fallen by 0.5 per cent over past two years amid pound’s slide and welfare cutsClick to followThe IndependentThe Brexit vote coupled with austerity has hurt household incomes more than anything other than recessions in the past 60 years and has done even more damage than the economic slump of the early 1990s, research has found.&nbspTypical household incomes have fallen by 0.5 per cent over the past two years compared with a rise of 0.3 per cent between 1991 and 1993, when the economy was going through and then recovering from recession, according to the annual Living Standards Audit by the Resolution Foundation.&nbspThe report dubs the latest period “Article 50 (so far)” in reference to the start of Britain’s withdrawal from the EU in March 2017.“Brexit has dominated the political landscape over the last three years, and even now it remains unclear just what form the UK’s exit from the EU will take,” it said.&nbsp“This uncertainty has already had a clear impact on growth and on living standards.”It added: “High inflation following the post-referendum sterling devaluation led to another fall&nbspin real wages. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCurrency extends losses, nearing parity with euro, after Johnson’s and Hunt’s remarks fan fears of no-deal BrexitClick to followThe IndependentThe pound has slipped further from a 27-month low against the dollar reached earlier and slid to a new six-month low against the euro.&nbspThe embattled currency tumbled on Tuesday after the two contenders to be Britain's next prime minister promised to scrap the Irish backstop – a key part of Theresa May’s Brexit agreement – amplifying fears of a no-deal Brexit.Stronger dollar pressured the exchange rate further on Wednesday, with the pound last trading at $1.2407. Sterling is nearing parity with the euro, with one pound now buying 1.1056&nbspeuro.Since the start of 2016, the pound has lost 15 per cent of its value against a basket of currencies that includes the dollar and the euro.Fears that Britain will crash out of the EU rose further on Tuesday after news emerged that Boris Johnson could send MPs home for up to two weeks in October if he becomes prime minister – a move that could prevent them stopping a no-deal Brexit.Both Johnson and his rival Jeremy Hunt had already refused to rule out a no-deal Brexit.&nbspThe weaker exchange rate will be felt keenly by people heading off on summer holidays abroad.&nbspAnalysis by Post Office Travel Money found that the pound has also declined against a number of other currencies used in popular destinations compared with this time last year, such as Thailand, Bali, Japan and Barbados. However,&nbspsterling has appreciated against currencies used in Turkey, Iceland and South Africa.Additional reporting by agenciesOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The Consumer Price Inflation measure&nbsptargeted by the central bank does not include the costs of owning and maintaining a home nor council tax.Clothing and footwear prices were among the very few components of the CPI that fell last month and at a much slower pace than in May.The steady course of inflation looks unlikely to last.&nbspSamuel Tombs, chief UK&nbspeconomist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said in a comment on Twitter that a weaker pound and a recent pick-up in wage growth point to higher inflation ahead.&nbsp&nbspThe pound fell to its lowest level against the dollar in more than two years on Tuesday after the two contenders to be Britain’s next prime minister promised&nbspto scrap the Irish backstop, amplifying&nbspfears of a no-deal Brexit.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Tariffs in the event of a no-deal Brexit  Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.There will be tariffs on pork in order to protect British farmersThere will be tariffs in place on some cheeses including €22.10100kg of cheddar, €19.10100kg of processed cheese and €18.60100kg on some blue cheesesThere will be no tariffs in place on milkThere will be no tariffs on car parts imported from EuropeThere will be no tariffs on alcoholic drinks - title: ed sheeran statue gorky park moscow tour
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsSheeran&nbspis performing in Moscow’s&nbspOtkritie&nbspArena this FridayClick to followThe Independent CultureAn enormous statue of Ed Sheeran believed to be 16 feet long has appeared overnight in Moscow’s Gorky Park, in what has been described as either an unusual promotional tool for Sheeran’s forthcoming concert in the city, or a terrifying Wicker Man-esque nightmare for all.The statue,&nbspa collaboration between&nbspYandex Music and Warner Music Russia,&nbspdepicts Sheeran reclining seductively in a pair of sunglasses while dressed in a graffiti-covered shirt and red shorts. Fine attention to detail has also meant that many of Sheeran’s tattoos have been replicated on his plastic doppelganger, too.Sheeran statue currently located in Gorky Park, Moscow (Yandex Music)On Twitter, one fan expressed their joy over the statue, writing: “Just in case Ed feels lonely in Russia, someone made this in the biggest park in Moscow.”Sheeran is performing in Moscow’s Otkritie Arena this Friday.Created with Sketch.The best albums of 2019 (so far) Show all 43Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.It’s not uncommon for an artist to be influenced by the place they grew up in. Yet few are likely to have as much inspiration to draw on as India-born, Zimbabwe-raised and now Peckham-based artist Rina Mushonga.On Deerhunter’s eighth album, frontman Bradford Cox takes on the role of war poet, documenting the things he observes with a cool matter-of-factness, and heart-wrenching detail. me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsThe technology giant also rejected allegations that it has been infiltrated by Chinese intelligence agentsClick to followThe Independent TechGoogle has finally said its controversial project to build a censored search engine for China has&nbspbeen terminated.Speaking at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Tuesday, Google's vice president of public policy Karan Bhatia&nbspsaid Project Dragonfly had been abandoned.The tech executive appeared at the hearing in Washington, DC, to face questions about Google's content policies,Her appearance came hours after US President Donald Trump said he will take a look at investigating Google for treason after Peter Thiel accused the technology giant of being infiltrated by Chinese agents.Mr&nbspBhatia told Republican Senator Josh Hawley at the hearing&nbspthat Google has seen no evidence that it has been infiltrated by Chinese intelligence agents and that it&nbspdid little business in China.Fundamentally in China we actually do very little today, certainly compared to any other major technology company, he said.Created with Sketch.Google staff stage walkout over handling of sexual misconduct Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Google employees hold signs outside 14th street park after walking out as part of a title: love island first look michael amber joanna greg hideaway
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsIn a sneak peek of tonight’s episode, Michael tells his fellow islanders: ‘I do actually like Amber’Click to followThe Independent CultureMichael Griffiths is set to make a confession in tonight’s (Wednesday’s) episode of Love Island, admitting&nbspthat he does actually have feelings for Amber Gill.In a sneak peek of the episode which was broadcast on ITV2, Griffiths appears to make a&nbspU-turn following Joanna Chimonides’ departure and decide that he does, in fact, fancy Amber after all.During a chat with his fellow islanders, Michael confesses: Now Joanna's gone I've had time to think about things and I do actually like Amber.The turnaround comes days after Joanna's exit and just hours after Amber's date with new islander&nbspGreg O’Shea.Created with Sketch. Show all 61Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.161 Lucie trying - and failing - to make ‘bev’ happenLove Island is known for adding new slang to the British lexicon, but 21-year-old Lucie’s firm insistence that ‘bev’ means a hot man failed to catch on.261 Amber’s anti-chemistry with Callum Straight-talking Amber quickly made mincemeat of Callum, the first boy she coupled up with. After correcting him when he said he looked younger than his 28 years, she confirmed it was his wrinkles which were aging him. She would go on to diss his sunglasses before ditching him for Anton during the next coupling.Sensitive boxer Tommy has been vocal about his love for Miley Cyrus’ teen sitcom since day one. His fandom reached new heights when he serenaded Curtis with a rendition of her hit song ‘The Climb’ to illustrate his path to winning Lucie’s heart. Aww.Blonde surfer Lucie was an instant hit in the villa, with almost every boy trying a cheeky graft. She seemed torn between Tommy and Joe, who each went nuclear in their attempt to woo her. Tommy pledged that he would crawl to the moon and back for her after knowing her for around 24 hours. Despite this, Joe’s jealous moping eventually won out. The confident Scotsman’s seduction skills manage to be both slippery smooth yet wildly erratic. His mile-a-minute chat has failed to land with any of the Love Island ladies, leading his to receive a cold shoulder from from Lucie, Anna and Mollie Mae. The raunchy challenge saw the boys strip down to chaps and speedos before hopping on a bucking bronco and getting covered in paint splatter. Performances ranged from smooth (Michael and Sherif) to deeply awkward (Callum and Joe).Amy had a minor wobble when newcomer Mollie Mae picked her man Curtis to join her for a date in the hot tub. She shouldn’t have worried: Curtis firmly friendzoned Mollie Mae and settled in for a gossip about his fellow housemates instead.Anton seemed confident at the first recoupling that pharmacist Anna would choose him. His confident smile on hearing Anna compliment her mystery love’s body quickly turned into disappointment when he realised she had been talking about Sherif.961 Calum leaves the villaThe aircraft engineer barely seemed to grace our screens before he was ejected after Mollie Mae chose to couple up with Tommy. 1061 Tommy makes his first cup of tea Tommy shocked the nation when he revealed he didn’t know how to make a cup of peppermint tea. With a lot of coaching from Sherif, the boxer managed to impress Mollie Mae without her realising the truth.1161 Tommy convinces himself he made an omeletteEncouraged by his success, Tommy tried to step up his culinary game by impressing Mollie Mae with a breakfast omelette (with Curtis doing the actual cooking.) Tommy even seemed to convince himself that he cooked the omelette, although he was rumbled after Sherif let slip who really made it.1261 Yewande’s quest for love Gorgeous scientist Yewande had been unlucky in love in the villa – until she was picked for a date by newcomer Danny. The rest of the Islanders encouraged her fledgling romance, from putting in a good word with Danny to criticising Mollie Mae’s attempt to woo the new boy for herself. Nine days into the series Love Island bosses confirmed that Sherif had been suddenly ejected from the show after “breaking the villa rules.” The 20-year-old confirmed his departure was due to his “poor judgement”, but it remains unknown which rule he broke. 1461 Curtis and Amy become a half-couple Amy may have never had a boyfriend before, but she was the first girl to make it official in the villa – sort of. During a date in the hideaway, Curtis asked her to become exclusive, which ended up with her getting the very high school label of ‘half-girlfriend.’1561 Amber opens up Amber gained a reputation for withering looks and cutting putdowns, but one man was able to get past her icy exterior. Firefighter Michael proved he could take her self-proclaimed a attitude, and was rewarded – on the second try – with a kiss.With Sherif out the villa, Anton resumed his moves on Anna. This time, it went even worse than before, with the Scotsman inadvertently comparing her with Mollie Mae, calling Anna beautiful ‘on the inside’. He thought the chat went well a dressing down from Amber and Michael soon put him in his place. Tommy was tasked with making a starter for his date with new girl Maura. “I’ve never put so much effort into cheese in my life,” he said, as he carved out lovehearts from limp sliced cheddar. The result, two slices of ketchup and mayo-smeared white bread, proved that Maura’s continuing lust for the 20-year-old boxer is made of powerful stuff. 1861 The girls freak out over Maura and Elma Amber, Yewande and Mollie Mae watched their respective partners meet the new girls from the balcony. “Confident sh*ts,” fumed Amber, while Mollie made fun of their flirty laughter.Michael brands Amber's behaviour as childish after the beauty therapist heckled his date with Maura.2061 Tommy and Mollie Mae fightMollie Mae wasn't happy when Tommy seemed interested in new girl Maura, and wasn't afraid to let the boxer know how she felt.2161 Amy and Lucie fall outLucie tearfully stood up for herself after Amy accused her of not spending enough time with the girls. Is Lucie just not a girl’s girl, or did Amy drive her away?2261 Maura gets a rise out of TommyMaura had her sights set on the 20-year-old boxer from the start, and things got steamy when she got him into bed. Her straight-up seduction techniques proved a bit too exciting for Tommy, who got a little hot and bothered under the covers. Just wait until he sees her eat an ice lolly…Maura went full factor 50 on Tommy when she ambushed him on the sofa. Tommy put his boxing training into practice as he dodged her kisses, while a jealous Mollie Mae watched on from behind a potted plant.2461 Jordan and Tom enter the villaAfter being the only two girls not picked for recoupling, Anna and Maura got to go on a date with the new boys: 29-year-old Tom and 24-year-old Jordan.2561 Joe and Elma leave the villaThe islanders voted for the couple they thought was least compatible, leaving the Joe-Lucie and Anton-Elma couples vulnerable. The public voted off Joe and Elma, ending the tumultuous relationship between the surfer and the sandwich maker (and leaving Anton single once again).2661 Anna and Jordan take it up a notchAnna and Jordan sealed the deal with a sensuous kiss, with Anna later rating the model as a 1010 kisser.2761 Arabella arrives – and immediately shakes things upAfter swearing to Yewande that a new girl wouldn’t turn his head, Danny was immediately smitten with fellow model Arabella after their flirty first date.2861 Yewande lays it on with DannySensing danger, Yewande made an effort to be more affectionate with Danny, kissing him in front of the rest of the islanders.During a challenge, a blindfolded Curtis accidentally rated Arabella a 1010 kisser, while giving his half-girlfriend Amy a measly seven. Amy was not happy, storming off followed by an apologetic Curtis.Arabella stirred the pot when she accused Yewande of being overly-possessive of Danny, telling her a few uncomplimentary remarks Danny had made about her to boot. A devastated Yewande soon realised that her fledgling romance was in serious jeopardy.3161 Maura is livid at TomMaura’s carrot-swallowing skills won her first place during the gym bunny challenge, giving her a night in the hideaway as a prize. Maura chose Tom to join her, but things quickly went south after she overheard him brag to the boys about finding out whether or not the Irish beauty was “all mouth.” Tom got a scathing dressing down, and a night in the hideaway was firmly off the cards.3261 Yewande leaves the islandDanny chose Arabella during a recoupling, leaving Yewande as the eliminated singleton. She was devastated to leave best mates Amber and Anna, but Danny was left with a scathing parting shot: “What goes around comes around.” Ouch.3361 Danny faces the wrath of AmberAmber was furious after watching Danny kiss Arabella the same night that Yewande left the villa. She had some choice words for the model, although Danny stayed calm and collected during the confrontation.3461 Curtis and Tommy share an intimate momentAfter declaring how much their friendship meant to each other, Tommy and Curtis shared the season’s first bromance kiss. Perhaps if they ditched their girlfriends, Turtis could go all the way to the £50k?During a challenge which saw the islanders read the public’s tweets, some couples were left seriously shaken. Amy was called out for making Curtis feel “in the wrong,” Lucie and Tommy were named as a good potential couple and Mollie Mae was accused of faking her relationship with Tommy for the prize money.3661 Mollie Mae worries about LucieThe Twitter challenge made Mollie Mae re-examine Tommy’s close friendship with Lucie. After a chat with Mollie Mae, the boxer told Lucie they should stop being so affectionate with each other. A disgruntled Lucie complained about the new “rules” imposed on her, while also refusing to rule out a potential relationship with Tommy during a chat with the girls.Maura wasn’t happy to hear that Tom had called her “attention-seeking” and “cringey” behind her back. She stormed over and confronted him, later making it clear he had blown his second chance.3861 Arabella and Tom get dumped from the islandAfter four couples were left vulnerable following a public vote, the three safe couples decided that Arabella and Tom should be the pair to leave the villa. Maura comforted a devastated Danny, but didn’t appear to be that heartbroken about losing Tom.3961 Lucie confesses her feelings for Tommy Encouraged by Anton, Lucie revealed to Tommy that she would be interested in rekindling their romance. Tommy told her he was happy with Mollie Mae, and later told Mollie about Lucie’s confession, leading Mollie to brand the Cornish surfer “muggy” for not coming to her first.4061 The girls take a holiday to Casa AmorSix new boys entered the game when the girls took a trip to Casa Amor. A thrilled Maura took an instant liking to Dennon, while 6ft 7in basketball player Ovie immediately cracked on with Anna, leaving her relationship with Jordan in jeopardy. 4161 Six new girls cause the boys to have doubtsBack at the villa, heads were also turning at the arrival of six new girls. Jordan flirted with Jourdan, Anton shared a bed with Belle and Danny seemed ready to move on from his Arabella heartbreak. Michael and Curtis began to question their own seemingly-solid partnerships, thanks to pretty newcomer Joanna. Anton remained hopeful about his odds of finally finding love: “I’ve got six new chances to not get pied.”4261 Curtis tells Jourdan he wants to recouple with herCurtis took a risk and laid it all out to Jourdan, telling her he would choose to recouple with her over Amy. title: pound dollar exchange rate latest sterling uk us brexit irish backstop euro
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCurrency extends losses, nearing parity with euro, after Johnson’s and Hunt’s remarks fan fears of no-deal BrexitClick to followThe IndependentThe pound has slipped further from a 27-month low against the dollar reached earlier and slid to a new six-month low against the euro.&nbspThe embattled currency tumbled on Tuesday after the two contenders to be Britain's next prime minister promised to scrap the Irish backstop – a key part of Theresa May’s Brexit agreement – amplifying fears of a no-deal Brexit.Stronger dollar pressured the exchange rate further on Wednesday, with the pound last trading at $1.2407. Sterling is nearing parity with the euro, with one pound now buying 1.1056&nbspeuro.Since the start of 2016, the pound has lost 15 per cent of its value against a basket of currencies that includes the dollar and the euro.Fears that Britain will crash out of the EU rose further on Tuesday after news emerged that Boris Johnson could send MPs home for up to two weeks in October if he becomes prime minister – a move that could prevent them stopping a no-deal Brexit.Both Johnson and his rival Jeremy Hunt had already refused to rule out a no-deal Brexit.&nbspThe weaker exchange rate will be felt keenly by people heading off on summer holidays abroad.&nbspAnalysis by Post Office Travel Money found that the pound has also declined against a number of other currencies used in popular destinations compared with this time last year, such as Thailand, Bali, Japan and Barbados. However,&nbspsterling has appreciated against currencies used in Turkey, Iceland and South Africa.Additional reporting by agenciesOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: giant manta ray diver removes fish hooks ningaloo reef western australia
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options'That manta absolutely understood what was going on. Jake went down again and again and she just remained still for him'Click to followThe IndependentA giant manta ray has been filmed appearing to beg a professional er for help saving her life.The three-metre-wide sea creature is shown swimming up to snorkelling guide Jake Wilton and flipping over in the water – apparently to show him fish hooks embedded in her right eye.The footage, caught near Ningaloo Reef off Western Australia’s north west coast, seems to show the manta ray then staying perfectly still as Mr Wilton gently removes the potentially deadly spikes.The animal – well known to locals and affectionately nicknamed Freckles – then swims away with a flourish as the er emerges triumphantly with the hooks.Monty Halls, a British marine biologist aboard the boat at the time, said: “That manta absolutely understood what was going on. Jake went down again and again and she just remained still for him.”Created with Sketch.Underwater Photographer of the Year Show all 45Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Winner: Behaviour and overall winner. I worry that this image will refuel the public's imbalanced perception of sharks but as an image capturing behaviour it has drama, adrenaline, grace, beauty and finality. That's a very rare combination in one image. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Winner: Wide Angle. The first moment I viewed this image I knew it would be a strong contender. For me it's the symmetry of the Humpback and the balance between the er and calf. Everything about it is in perfect alignment. The shape of the tail in relation to the four corners of the frame, not to mention the position of the free er and calf. Superb imagery at its very best.  Many congratulations Francois. - Martin Edge (Judge)    Winner: Macro. Fabio’s use of long exposure and panning has turned a classic portrait of a Sepiola into an unforgettable one. The sharp and ghosted images of the bobtail squid balance pleasingly in the frame and combined with the outstretched tentacles give the feeling of the cephalopod lunging for its prey. An innovative and most deserving category winner. - Alex Mustard (Judge) It is hard to imagine what it must have been like to have experienced such a large scale natural spectacle as this but this image, perfectly composed and timed, gets close. - Peter Rowlands (Judge) Winner: British Waters Macro. A mantra of mine is 'It's not what it is. It's where it is' and this long clawed Squat lobster is in a perfect position to make a memorable image. The author, instead of 'blasting' it with light, has gone in the opposite direction by restricting the strobe into a snooted spotlight in order to illuminate just the features of the lobster and the dainty sea loch anemones. It's an example of 'Isolation lighting' at its very best. A great deal of uw photographers invest their time in what they want to illuminate. This is an example which in my opinion illustrates features that they do not want to illuminate, hence the punchy black background and the soft delicate hues of dark sand, facial features topped off by the sea loch anemones. - Martin Edge (Judge)Winner: Marine Conservation. The problems of plastic pollution and ghost fishing are both illustrated by this struggling loggerhead turtle. I am happy to learn this inidual was lucky enough to survive this deathtrap thanks to the photographer - Alex Mustard (Judge)What a chin, what a forehead, what a character. This picture has portrait written all over it, and such a fascinating species ideally suited to this close focus wide angle approach. - Alex Mustard (Judge) Winner: Portrait. Superb impact from the very first moment it was presented. Perfect composition within the image frame and the understated colours. To top it off the authors comments above say it all... a Smiling Happy Angel's Face. One of my favourites from the entire competition. - Martin Edge (Judge)  Winner: Up &amp Coming. title: the inbetweeners 3 faceapp james buckley joke twitter 2060 sequel aged image
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsHere’s what the hapless friends would look like in a third movie set 40 years in the futureClick to followThe Independent CultureThe Inbetweeners cast has shared photos imagining what a 2060 sequel would look like, with the help of FaceApp’s aging tool.James Buckley, who played Jay, first posted the unsettling image on Instragram with the jokey caption: “The 1st official photo of the 3rd Inbetweeners movie has been released.”Blake Harrison, who starred as Neil, soon followed suit, posting on Twitter: “Here’s to a reunion episode in 2060!”The beloved sitcom, which also featured Simon Bird as Will and Joe Thomas as Simon, ran on Channel 4 from 2008 to 2010. Fans were then reunited with the hapless friends in films in 2011 and 2014.Created with Sketch.37 sequels that are even better than the original Show all 37Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Ridley Scott's Alien may be an acclaimed horror film, but sequel Aliens – directed by James Cameron – is a stone cold action classic. Gone is the ignorant Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) of the original in favour of a hardened badass who returns to the moon, accompanied by a group of space marines, to take on the alien queen. How many years between sequel and original? SevenIt wasn't until the arrival of Austin Powers sequel The Spy Who Shagged Me that Mike Myers's comic creations were fully wedged into the hearts of film lovers. If the original was the perfect introduction to Austin's groovy world, the follow-up was an altogether funnier, bigger and more quotable affair. How many years between sequel and original? TwoCapping off not only your own franchise but a decade-long series consisting of 22 films is no mean feat – and yet Avengers: Endgame balanced all the playing pieces to do so with gargantuan success. How many years between sequel and original? Seven437 Back to the Future Part II (1989)The first sequel to Robert Zemeckis's Back to the Future is an amusing adventure that sees Marty McFly (Michael J Fox) travel... well, back to the future, to prevent his own son from sabotaging the family legacy. How many years between sequel and original? FourIt was the addition of both Michelle Pfeiffer and Danny DeVito – as Catwoman and the Penguin, respectively – that made Tim Burton's sequel Batman Returns an even more memorable watch than the original. How many years between sequel and original? ThreeEach instalment of Richard Linklater's Before trilogy is as good as the last. But, if there is a peak, it surely arrives with number two – Before Sunset – which reunites would-be lovers Jesse (Ethan Hawke) and Celine (Julie Delpy) nine years after they first met in Before Sunrise (1995). How many years between sequel and original? NineThere's a blistering chase sequence midway through The Bourne Ultimatum involving Matt Damon's amnesiac spy and journalist Simon Ross (Paddy Considine). It's adeptly directed by Paul Greengrass – here at the top of his game – and is all the proof you need that the original trilogy improved with each new film. How many years between sequel and original? Five837 Bride of Frankenstein (1935)Depicting Mary Shelley's classic creature as a pleasant guy just looking for a companion, Bride of Frankenstein is one of the greatest monster movies, let alone sequels, in cinema history. How many years between sequel and original? FourBatman Begins may have been the perfect origin story for the caped crusader, but nothing could have prepared film fans for the classic its sequel would become. Christopher Nolan intelligently crafted The Dark Knight into one of the greatest follow-ups ever made, with several standout action sequences and an untouchable performance from Heath Ledger as the Joker. One for the ages. How many years between sequel and original? Three1037 Dawn of the Dead (1978)George A Romero ditched the entire cast of Night of the Living Dead for its first sequel, Dawn of the Dead, which showed the effects of the zombie apocalypse on a much larger scale than depicted in the black-and-white original. One of the most entertaining horror films ever made.  How many years between sequel and original? 10The glory you feel watching Hellboy II: The Golden Army comes from the knowledge that you're watching a studio allow Guillermo del Toro to do whatever the hell he wants. A scintillating oddity of a follow-up that surpasses the 2004 original within minutes. How many years between sequel and original? FourNot so much an improvement on the first as one that rips up its rule book completely: Sam Raimi took the character of Ash (Bruce Campbell), who viewers first met in influential 1981 horror The Evil Dead,&nbspand placed him in the heart of what is essentially a slapstick comedy. How many years between sequel and original? SixAfter the lacklustre fourth instalment, Fast &amp Furious 5 was the reinvention the series desperately needed. Bringing in Dwayne Johnson as the bad guy was a genius stroke and the final set-piece – a car dragging a bank vault through the streets of Rio – remains as entertaining as anything the long-running series has ever done. How many years between sequel and original? 10The Godfather Part II set the highest benchmark for what sequels should be, but so rarely are – a crucial chapter in a saga. The film won Robert De Niro an Oscar for his efforts, playing the same role Marlon Brando won an Oscar for two years before. This, alongside another film on this list, is one of two sequels to ever win Best Picture (keep scrolling to find out the other one). How many years between sequel and original? Two1537 The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)The fact that Sergio Leone had barely any money to make The Good, the Bad and the Ugly – the third film in his Man With no Name trilogy – fortuitously led to the casting of the relatively unknown Clint Eastwood. Leone's film, beautifully soundtracked by Ennio Morricone, is a masterwork that proves less is more: its most classic dialogue-free scenes derived from the fact that Leone had no time to shoot dialogue. How many years between sequel and original? Two1637 Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)Gone was the warm glow of Hogwarts in Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. Alfonso Cuarón's adaptation of the JK Rowling novel proved the franchise could win widespread acclaim, as well as ticket receipts, if put in the hands of interesting directors. How many years between sequel and original? Three1737 How to Train Your Dragon 2 (2014)Could How to Train Your Dragon endure as one of the most beloved yet underrated franchises of all time? Quite possibly – and its first sequel, which features breathless flight sequences and animation to marvel at, is solid evidence of this. How many years between sequel and original? FourDespite essentially rehashing the plot of the first film, The Hunger Games: Catching Fire is a bolder, more exciting and, yes, deadlier outing for Jennifer Lawrence's heroine Katniss Everdeen. How many years between sequel and original? One1937 Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989)If Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade isn't better than series opener Raiders of the Lost Ark, it's certainly as good. This is thanks to the addition of Sean Connery's Henry Jones Sr – the father of Harrison Ford's whip-cracking archaeologist. How many years between sequel and original? EightPerhaps it was down to relief that Iron Man 3 was so revered by critics (lest we forget Iron Man 2 is one of Marvel's biggest duds). But, Robert Downey Jr's third solo outing as Tony Starl boasts enough laughs and thrills, not to mention a doozy of a twist, that earns its placement on this list. How many years between sequel and original? FiveLethal Weapon 2 takes what made the original so fun – the wit and twist-filled action – and amps it up as far as it can possibly go. That it throws in Joe Pesci for good measure just makes the results even more sizzling. How many years between sequel and original? TwoLogan rectified the mistakes of Wolverine's earlier standalone films thanks to James Mangold's decision to place the character in a far grittier film than he was used to (it was rated 15 in the UK). The result remains a perfect send-off to one of X-Men's greatest characters, who first played the role in 2000.How many years between sequel and original? 17Gareth Evans's sequel to The Raid is more of the glorious same, only – somehow – more ambitious. Two hours and 30 minutes of breathlessly-paced fight sequences that's unlike anything caught on film before. How many years between sequel and original? Three2437 The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)The second sequel to ever win Best Picture is all about the payoff. While each film in Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy delivers in what it needs to, this final chapter balances all the plates to dish out an epic conclusion that surely would have been everything JRR Tolkien wanted from an adaptation of his classic novels. The Consumer Price Inflation measure&nbsptargeted by the central bank does not include the costs of owning and maintaining a home nor council tax.Clothing and footwear prices were among the very few components of the CPI that fell last month and at a much slower pace than in May.The steady course of inflation looks unlikely to last.&nbspSamuel Tombs, chief UK&nbspeconomist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said in a comment on Twitter that a weaker pound and a recent pick-up in wage growth point to higher inflation ahead.&nbsp&nbspThe pound fell to its lowest level against the dollar in more than two years on Tuesday after the two contenders to be Britain’s next prime minister promised&nbspto scrap the Irish backstop, amplifying&nbspfears of a no-deal Brexit.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Tariffs in the event of a no-deal Brexit  Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.There will be tariffs on pork in order to protect British farmersThere will be tariffs in place on some cheeses including €22.10100kg of cheddar, €19.10100kg of processed cheese and €18.60100kg on some blue cheesesThere will be no tariffs in place on milkThere will be no tariffs on car parts imported from EuropeThere will be no tariffs on alcoholic drinks - story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options‘I don’t know how I can maintain this face of joy and warmth,’ workers&nbspon lowest wages sayClick to followThe Independent USThe heiress to the Disney fortune has criticised the company’s top boss after discovering Disneyland workers are being forced to “forage for food in the garbage” during a secret visit.Abigail Disney decided to take matters into her own hands and tour California’s Disneyland undercover after receiving a Facebook message from an employee struggling to make ends meet.The 59-year-old said she found “The Happiest Place on Earth” was in fact full of people forcing smiles onto their faces as they tried not to bend under the pressure of not being able to pay basic bills.She told Yahoo News: “Every single one of these people I talked to were saying ‘I don’t know how I can maintain this face of joy and warmth when I have to go home and forage for food in other people’s garbage’.”The documentary filmmaker said she was “livid” because her grandfather Roy O Disney taught her to “revere these people that take your tickets, that pour your soda”.Created with Sketch. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsFormer German defence minister is first woman to hold Brussels’ top jobClick to followThe IndependentThe European parliament has narrowly approved Ursula von der Leyen as the next president of the European Commission, replacing&nbspJean-Claude Juncker at the helm of the EU’s executive.The German defence minister was approved by 383&nbspvotes to 327, with 22 abstentions and one blank vote&nbspon Tuesday evening. She needed 374 votes to reach the threshold to be elected, meaning she scraped through by just nine votes.Ms Von der Leyen, who was nominated by EU leaders earlier this month,&nbspis the first woman to hold the top job in Brussels. The European Commission is the union’s executive arm and is responsible for proposing EU law, enforcing its treaties, and representing the interests of the bloc as a whole on the world stage.&nbspShe is due to take office on 1 November after a handover period during which her cabinet of commissioners, one from each member state, will be chosen and their portfolios allocated. She has pledged to achieve gender balance in the top team – but could face a showdown with member state governments, who may have other candidates in mind as their commissioners.The German politician’s appointment is controversial because she&nbspwas not a lead&nbspcandidate in the EU elections last month. The European parliament had previously said that the next commission president should have been on the ballot paper during the contest and campaigned across the EU, under the so-called “spitzenkandidat” system.New EU commission cabinet will be half women, says Juncker replacementUrsula von der Leyen: the German minister set to run the EUEU leaders back Ursula von der Leyen to be commission presidentBut a majority of&nbspMEPs gave Ms Von der Leyen their backing anyway after national leaders called their bluff and proposed a candidate who was not available to vote for. She was opposed by MEPs from the green and left groups in the parliament, but supported by the centre-right and the liberals. The centre-left socialist group was split, with some countries’ parties such as the German SPD opposing the appointment and others such as Labour supporting it.“The trust you placed in me is the confidence you placed in Europe,” she told MEPs in her acceptance speech.&nbsp“Your confidence in a united and a strong Europe, from east to west, from south to north. Your confidence in a Europe that is ready to fight for the future rather than fighting against each other. Your confidence in a Europe that will take the big challenges of our times together. title: ancient metropolis jerusalem israel motza middle east
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsIsraeli archaeologists&nbspclaim to have found Middle East’s largest ever&nbspNeolithic excavationClick to followThe IndependentAn enormous Neolithic settlement described by archaeologists as an ancient “metropolis” has been discovered only three miles outside of Jerusalem.The 9,000-year-old site was located next&nbspto the modern day town of Motza by scientists with the Israeli Antiquities&nbspAuthority (IAA) – who claimed it represented a “Big Bang” moment in the field of prehistorical research.“It’s a game changer, a site that will drastically shift what we know about the Neolithic era,” Jacob Vardi, co-director of the excavations at the site.Stretching over half a kilometre, the Stone Age city would have been home to around 3,000 people. Mr Vardi&nbspdescribed&nbspthe complex society as the ancient equivalent of Jerusalem or Tel Aviv – “a real metropolis”.Before the discovery, it was widely believed the entire area had been uninhabited in the period, during which people were still shifting from hunting to a more sedentary lifestyle.Created with Sketch.Archaeologists uncover nearly 5,000 cave paintings in Burgos, Mexico Show all 4Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.One of 5,000 cave paintings uncovered in north MexicoMexican National Institute of Anthropology One of 5,000 cave paintings uncovered in north MexicoMexican National Institute of Anthropology The ruins were only uncovered during a preliminary survey conducted for the construction of a new highway in the area.A wider excavation exposed large buildings, alleyways and burial places, evidence of a relatively advanced level of planning, the antiquities authority said in a statement.“This is most probably the largest excavation of this time period in the Middle East, which will allow the research to advance leaps and bounds ahead of where we are today, just by the amount of material that we are able to save and preserve from this site,” said Lauren Davis, an archaeologist with the antiquities team.Vardi at Motza site (AFPGetty Images)The team also found storage sheds that contained large quantities of legumes, particularly lentils, whose seeds were remarkably preserved throughout the millennia.Also found were flint tools, including thousands of arrowheads, axes for chopping down trees, sickle blades and knives.“This finding is evidence of an intensive practice of agriculture,” according to the&nbspIAA statement. “Animal bones found on the site show that the settlement’s residents became increasingly specialised in sheep-keeping, while the use of hunting for survival gradually decreased.”Additional reporting by ReutersOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your title: prime minister tory leader odds news
story: Here we look at the latest bookies odds on Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt, who are fighting to be the next Prime Minister.Boris Johnson remains the runaway favourite to be the next Prime Minister and Tory leader.Here are what the bookies are saying on July , , according to Paddy Power.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is still a hugely popular figure among Tory grassroots and the general public.Boris quit as Foreign Secretary in July , just hours after Theresa May lost Brexit Secretary David Davis over her Chequers plan to keep close ties to Brussels.He called on May to stop dithering and tell the EU that Britain will not accept the controversial backstop arrangement designed to avoid a hard border in Ireland.The -year-old also pledged to pay for a massive tax break for million Brits through money reserved for a No Deal exit - despite being open to a No Deal.He began his campaign a little later than the other candidates on June , in a bid perhaps to steal some of their thunder.He vowed to deliver a super-fast Brexit.Mr Hunt was the longest-serving Health Secretary in British historybefore replacing Boris as Foreign Secretary.He left the Department of Health after securing a £bn funding increase for the NHS, but was hated by junior doctors after changing their contracts so they wouldnt receive extra pay for the many shts they work - previously classied as unsociable hours.Despite campaigning for Remain during the referendum, Hunt now backs the UKs withdrawal from the EU.Just hours after Mrs May resigned, he put his name into the hat to be in the running to replace her.On June , Trade Secretary Liam Fox threw his support behind Hunt in a surprise move, followed by two heavyweights - prominent leaver and defence secretary Penny Mordaunt and work and pensions secretary Amber Rudd.Hunt opened his leadership bid by claiming the new PM might not be able to start renegotiating with the EU until November  because its new Commission only starts then.The two men fighting to become Tory leader went up against each other in a head-to-head clash over Brexit, benefits and Donald Trump.Johnson and Hunt both vowed they would keep hated Universal Creditthey became PM - but the underdog hinted he would cut the five-week wait for cash.Both of them committed to keeping the flagship welfare policy in placethey made it into Downing Street in just two weeks time.However, Mr Hunt, the underdog in the contest, admitted it had teething problems and said: We need to deal with the five-week wait which has caused a lot of distress.The Department for Work and Pensions insists that no Brit has to wait five weeks for their first payment as they can get an advance of up to  per cent as soon as they apply.Both candidates said they intend to leave the UK by October .But Johnson seems more likely to push through a No Deal Brexit than Hunt.However Johnson denies there will be a disorderly Brexit and promises to avoid a no deal.Hunt says it will be very seriousa No Deal is necessary, and says he has a ten-point Brexit plan to avoid that outcome.Johnson however wants to prepare for No Deal and claims we will have £billion to spend on it.Hunt told Donald Trump his comments about Theresa May were unacceptable.Johnson says he has a strong relationship with the White House, but didnt give a conclusive answer about the presidents comments.Hunt would not sack the UK ambassador to the US, Sir Kim Darroch, as a reaction to Trump saying he wouldnt deal with him, meanwhile Johnson would not answer the question.Theresa May stepped down as Tory leader without delivering Brexit and with her party on the verge of extinction.May claimed she had done all she could to take Britain out of the EU with a deal, saying: Ever since I first stepped through the door behind me as Prime Minister, I have striven to make the United Kingdom a country that works not just for a privileged few, but for everyone. And to honour the result of the EU referendum.If you give people a choice you have a duty to implement what they decide. I have done my best to do that.Sadly I have not been able to do so. I tried three times - I believe it was right to persevere even when the odds against success seemed high.May survived a vote of no confidence in December , but repeated thwarted attempts to pass her Brexit deal left her without authority.May will remain as Prime Minister until a new party leader is announced in the week beginning July .

title: sun readers debate boris hunt live
story: Both teams appeared much more relaxed this time around compared to last weeks ITV debate.There were jokes aplenty and both candidates ribbed each other and were well received by the upbeat audience.Boris tripped up a bit over immigration and refused to commit to getting the numbers down.But he did rule out an early election # something which will make many Tories extremely happy.They both attacked Donald Trump over his comments about democratic congresswomen, but refused to call him a racist.And they both agreed to having at least one top woman in their Cabinetthey become PM next week.All in all, both Boris and Hunt did well. Most of them answered the question honestly but had a decent dig at each other as they went.All in all, a very entertaining debate filled with fun # and some news too.In just a week’s time we will know which of these two men will be your next Prime Minister.Thanks to everyone for watching, and our fantastic readers for sending in their questions.We’ll have all the reaction from outside Sun Towers to the debate coming up.And on talkRADIO Ross Kempsell will have all the analysis of the last hour’s debate.And now it’s time for our quick-fire round of questions, to finish off the debate.# climate change target of net zero emissions by  keep it  Boris: YesHunt:Yes# continue to freeze fuel duty, like the last  years Boris: Not making any more spending commitments. title: mps lords houses in order karren brady
story: Nearly two years on from #MeToo, two new reports paint a bleak picture of sexual harassment in Westminster.The first report, about the House of Lords, found that one in five peers was considered to behave in an inappropriate or high-handed way to staff. One Lord was described as a “notorious bullying pervert” by a Westminster worker.The verdict was that the prevailing culture and behaviour in the House of Lords “has not been conducive to an open and supportive culture to ensure all those working there are treated with dignity and respect”.Worse, the report concluded those staff on the receiving end of bullying and harassment generally did not complain because they thought nothing would change, or feared reprisal.Clearly, the House of Lords has issues. But it’s nowhere near as bad as the House of Commons. The second report, by Gemma White QC into inappropriate conduct in Westminster, concluded MPs’ staff face “unacceptable risk of bullying and harassment”.It found sexual harassment in Parliament is seen by young staff as a “necessary evil”they want to progress. Witnesses describe speaking out against any abuse as “career suicide”.Even though both reports state only a small minority of MPs or Lords behave in unacceptable ways, this has been tolerated for too long and shining a light on it will bring about change.What’s clear to me, both from reading the report and working at the House of Lords, is that this is a generational issue. The House of Lords is full of older people stuck in a time warp.Many of them live in a world where it’s still acceptable for women — often females of a lower status to them — to be patted on the bottom or on the head.The House of Lords can feel a bit like a boys’ boarding school, or Hogwarts. It’s populated predominantly by old white men, many of whom lead a le insulated from the real world.That said, the worst behaviour I witness is usually in the library, where Lords often retire after lunch and which rings with the sound of ear-deafening snoring and, I am sorry to say, farting.The only time I’ve ever seen anyone being actively rude was when one Lord commanded a member of canteen staff to get him a bag of crisps. He was so close he could have reached out and got it himself.I’ve also been on the receiving end of the odd condescending comment, such as when a Lord looked me up and down and said: “You’re dressed rather casually.” I was wearing Stella McCartney trousers at the time, so not exactly jeans.Crucially, though, I wasn’t wearing a dress. So I looked him up and down and said: “Dressing casually is better than dressing badly” — and that was the end of that.It must be horrible to work in an organisation where you feel inferior and can’t speak your mind — and,you do, people either shrug or shut you down. The report about the House of Lords suggested it should be mandatory for all employees to go on a “how to value people” course. Some people might see it as unnecessary — but we send West Ham staff on them and they are good.But that’s not the only change required. There’s neither enough women, nor cultural ersity. The only way that will change is by electing a more erse chamber.In the meantime, I hope this report does not diminish, in people’s minds, the important legislation work the House of Lords does and the role it plays in holding the Commons to account. I hope these reports don’t stop people from remembering what an important institution it is.As Spider-Man said: “With great power comes great responsibility” — and as one who sits in the House of Lords, I know I am not the only one who feels it is a great responsibility.BIG news. MPs have voted to make same-sex marriage legal in Northern Ireland.By a massive margin of  to , the House of Commons backed an amendment demanding the province be brought into line with the rest of the country by October  . . . unless Stormont s and decides otherwise. About time, too.Equally groundbreaking was the House also endorsing a move to liberalise abortion laws by  to  in another crucial vote. Those results came after MPs hijacked a Government Bill in a bid to force through the changes.The DUP has accused them of abusing the impasse at Stormont to impose Westminster’s will. So not everyone is happy with the news.But it’s a big “Hooray!” from me that this kind of right-minded thinking now applies to the whole UK. After all, women have the right to choose what happens to their bodies.And what dference does it make – and whose business is it  – who you love and make love to I FEEL for Donna Bettiss, who is selling her unworn wedding dress after her fiance left her for their wedding planner.Donna, , from Horsham in West Sussex, was devastated when partner James Routledge, , dumped her last year just weeks before their big day. He then started a relationship with work colleague Paige Hannington, , who had helped the couple organise their wedding.Let’s hope Donna gets back the £, the dress is worth. What a cad. Leaving your bride-to-be for the wedding planner is NOT a good look.The only consolation – though Donna might not see it quite yet – is that she is almost certainly better off without him.WHEN I heard a Hull mum had called two of her children Jackdaniel and Tiamarie, all I could think was, “poor kids”.But mum Sarah Mennell insists they aren’t named after booze, as she prefers tea. So I guess the kids got lucky. They could have been called Lionelrichtea and Maryland instead.STRONG contender here for the World’s Gone Mad award.Mum Beth McKenna answered her front door to police who were there after an anonymous tip-off from someone concerned about the welfare of her children.The reason  The kids were in her garden, playing naked in a paddling pool.Beth, from Walkergate, Newcastle upon Tyne, said she “couldn’t believe it” when two unormed police officers turned up at her home on Thursday. And, frankly, who can blame her I AM saddended to hear that the woman who beat a host of men to be named Plasterer Of The Year has been trolled online – and even sent fake porn pictures of her ten-year-old daughter.Steph Leese, , from Liverpool, claims that within  minutes of the announcement, she was bombarded with vile abuse from male plasterers.One person put dog mess through her post box, with a note claiming: “This is what we think of your work.”Men really don’t like it when ladies trespass on what they see as their territory . . . and do a better job.ANYONE  do a double-take looking at photos of Ed Sheeran sporting a really bad mullet Luckily, it turns out it’s just a wig. Love your music, Ed. I’m not sure about your style.I KNOW times are hard but travel agents are now offering package trips that centre around excursions to . . . the world’s biggest Primark. That’s right. You can book a night in a hotel in Birmingham, followed by a Primark shopping excursion.Sure, it’s set over five floors, has three restaurants and it has a hair and beauty salon.But still. title: ross clark basu press leaks democracy
story: Police claim to be so overstretched that in some parts of the country they are refusing even to investigate  per cent of reported crimes.Yet at the same time, the politan Police seem quite happy to commit resources to investigate the leaking of diplomatic cables which embarrassed Sir Kim Darroch, who, until his resignation last week, was our man in Washington.Even more bizarrely, the Met has set its Counter Terrorism Command on the operation — yes, the unit that is supposed to spend its time stopping extremists blowing us up. It has threatened journalists, too, that they face prosecutionthey dare to publish the content of the cables.Trying to justy his threats, the Met’s Assistant Commissioner, Neil Basu, said he was sure the leaks had “damaged UK international relations” and on that basis no one publishing the leaks could plead a public interest defence.What a ludicrous over-reaction to what is really no more than a diplomatic spat over the Ferrero Rochers.Sure, it doesn’t exactly help UK US relations when our Ambassador calls the President of the United States “inept” and his administration “uniquely dysal”.But I would say it is mildly less damaging than some of the things that the Leader of Opposition, the Mayor of London and Scotland’s First Minister have said about Donald Trump. I can’t see Mr Basu dangling his handcuffs in front of them — and neither should he.Obviously, Sir Kim has reason to feel aggrieved that someone — presumably in the diplomatic service or the Foreign Office, because there is no evidence of computers being hacked — has leaked information he intended to be private. But it is a matter for the Government to investigate, not the police.How ridiculous Basu has said of the leaker: “You are now also responsible for erting busy detectives from under-taking their core mission.”No, Mr Basu — it is only thanks to your decision that officers have been taken off front-line duties to undertake this investigation.You could have told officials what police officers are forever telling the rest of us when we report our houses broken into or our bikes stolen: Sorry, but we’ve got too much  to do.It would be a dferent mattersomeone had leaked material that really did harm national security.The sort of information leaked by Kim Philby and his Soviet-sympathising accomplices in the s put British lives at risk.But leaking and publishing a diplomat’s private thoughts hardly comes into that category. Mr Basu’s attack on the principles of the free Press echoes Operation Elveden, the failed attempt by the Met to criminalise journalists who had obtained information from police officers, in some cases for money.The Met switched more than  police officers from other duties and arrested  people. The police probe cost taxpayers £.million and yet of  journalists charged, only one was convicted at trial — and that was quashed on appeal. Just one journalist, Dan Evans, pleaded guilty to an Elveden offence and was given a suspended sentence.The prosecutions relied on an ancient offence, Misconduct in Public Office, which was only ever supposed to apply to public servants, not journalists.As many lawyers, including the Lord Chief Justice, pointed out, it simply isn’t a criminal offence for someone to receive or to publish most forms of state information — only for a public official to sell it.There is a very good reason for this. Leaks, and the freedom to put their contents into the public domain, are an essential ingredient of our democracy. It is what helps the Press to keep in check corrupt or over-bearing politicians and public officials.Without the freedom to publish leaked information, for example, we would never have known the extent to which MPs and Lords were abusing their expenses regime.That required a newspaper to publish information gleaned from a computer disk which had been stolen — but thankfully in that case the Met decided that the public interest over-rode a possible offence of handling stolen goods.Without the Panama Papers we would never have known the extent to which wealthy iniduals and corporations have gone into keeping their wealth out of the taxman’s grasp. Without the “climategate” leaks we would not have known how some climate scientists were prepared to manipulate past temperature records to support their theories.It took a leak, too, to establish that the Blair government knew it was unlikely that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, but that George W Bush had resolved to overthrow Saddam regardless.Then there was “Plebgate”, when a leaked police log revealed a bust-up between government chief whip Andrew Mitchell and police manning the gates at Downing Street — and led an officer to be jailed when it was revealed he had invented his witness statement.There are, of course, plenty of other countries in the world where journalists would be locked up for publishing information that has leaked from the government, but they are not countries in which most of us would want to live.By over-reacting to what is an embarrassment to the Foreign Office, the Met has taken a leaf out of the book of President Erdogan of Turkey, who has locked up dozens of journalists as he attempts to suppress all opposition to his regime.Neil Basu and other senior Met Police officers should back off and accept that the Press is quite within its rights to publish leaked information that does not threaten national security.We are, after all, one of the world’s oldest ing democracies — not a tinpot state where people get led off in chains for daring to reveal the truth. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The bizarre creature can be seen moving slowly along a pavement in the southern state of Santa Catarina in stomach-turning footage.Tori Silveira, , spotted it as she made her way to the supermarket.She said: “I leaned in to get a better look and saw that it was a bunch of little bugs that I had never seen before around here.“My first impression [was] very much ‘Woah, what the f*** is that ’“Id describe it as hundreds of long, black worm-like bugs with tiny legs crawling on top of each other, slowly moving down a sidewalk astheyre migrating to a new area together.“Im still not entirely sure what kind of bug they are.“Some say caterpillar, others say wasp larvae.
